Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research: Understanding Lay Theories of Environmental Change, Climate Change, and Adaptation in Southern Appalachia

The research funded by this award will investigate lay observations of environmental change: how people who live in a particular place use their own experiences to understand change in the natural world. The research will be conducted by Dr. Meredith Welch-Devine (University of Georgia) and Dr. Brian J. Burke (Appalachian State University), anthropologists affiliated with the NSF-supported Coweeta Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) Program in southern Appalachia. Drawing on more than 80 years of data, Coweeta scientists have developed projections of future environmental change in the region and have outlined anticipated effects on local biodiversity and ecosystems. Their scientific findings provide a rich resource for local environmental governance and adaptation planning. In parallel, local non-scientist residents of the same region have gathered their own experiential data on biodiversity and change, transmitting it across generations and developing their own theories of its causes and consequences. Unfortunately, such local theories are rarely studied systematically even though they can be contribute significantly to science and to improved policy making. Place-based theories enhance science findings by connecting broad-scale changes to specific locations and micro-level change processes, as well as to the livelihoods, landscapes, and issues that move people to act. Because lay theories can significantly shape how we as a society respond and adapt to the changes around us, it is important to understand where local knowledge comes from and how it is affected by local history, economy, and culture.

The Coweeta region provides an ideal venue for such an investigation because of the availability of comparative scientific data. Also, the region is home to a mix of long-term and newcomer populations with different ways of engaging the natural world. For some residents, nature provides their livelihood, while others have been drawn to the area by its scenic beauty and recreation opportunities. Recognizing that plants and animals are central to people's experiences of their environment, the researchers have chosen to focus on perceptions of biodiversity. They will construct a sample of 90 local residents stratified by how long they and their families have lived in the area (multi-generational residents, one or two generation residents, and newcomers). The researchers will conduct life history and environmental interaction interviews with all members of the sample. An additional 45 residents will be asked to complete comprehensive freelisting exercises to elicit their cognitive models of the natural world, which will be complemented with follow-up interviews focused on changes in the freelisted items. The researchers will also conduct semi-structured interviews with resource managers and environmental policy makers; analyze official documents for differential inclusion of local and scientific knowledge and concerns in policy making; and conduct participant observation at relevant community events. Findings will document how local non-scientists experience and understand the same environmental changes that Coweeta scientists are measuring and recording. Parallel research, funded elsewhere, is being conducted in France, Zimbabwe, and Cameroon; data will be analyzed at the country level and then across the four countries through synthesis workshops. The overall goal is to understand how perceptions of environmental change vary, why they vary, and what the implications are for planning and policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research examined the development of place-based knowledge among residents of Southern Appalachia. We studied how people observe and interpret changes in their environments and how they plan for a future that is likely to be more extreme and unpredictable. Because effective responses to environmental change often require collective action based on a broad range of knowledge, concerns, and values, as well as careful work to manage conflicts among stakeholders, we were especially interested in understanding the diversity of observations, knowledge, and values in the region.

 

To capture this diversity, we asked how people's connections to place influence the things they observe, the changes they care about, and how they make sense of those changes. We interviewed more than 150 residents of four counties in western North Carolina to explore differences in environmental knowledge based on (1) whether people are new to the region or come from families who have been there for generations, (2) whether people interact with the environment primarily through work or recreation, and (3) how people use knowledge from other places to interpret local changes.


Our interviewees identified 882 species. Residential status (whether someone was a multigenerational resident or a newcomer) did not affect the number of species mentioned but had several important effects: (1) multigenerational residents were more homogeneous in their observations, noting many of the same species and changes, while newcomers talked about a broader range of species; (2) multigenerational residents were more likely to discuss domesticated species or species with economic value, while newcomers were more likely to discuss wild species, invasive species, and birds; and (3) multigenerational residents and newcomers had different emotional responses to the loss of particular plants and animals. For example, while multigenerational residents often focused on chestnut trees, newcomers often spoke about the decline of the hemlock. The other two variables—whether people interacted with the environment through work or recreation and how they used knowledge from other places—had smaller effects on observations, knowledge, and concerns.

 

We also interviewed several professional environmental managers. Their observations and interpretations were framed according to day-to-day job responsibilities and the impacts over which they had direct control, rather than the science in general or popular perceptions. For example, resource managers whose work entails forest fire suppression described how previous years’ weather affected their work. Though they were aware that long-term climate change affects these conditions, they were uninterested in examining long-term impacts in more detail because budgetary and administrative constraints had a much bigger impact on their work. In addition, though resource managers thought that lay people's observations could be interesting as a gauge of public opinion, they seemed generally dismissive of considering these a guide for resource management.

 

This research suggests, first, that including many different types of local residents (not just those you expect to have detailed knowledge of a place) could result in better knowledge gathering for decision-making. Different residential groups see different patterns and changes in the environment as a result of their differing social and spatial relationships to species. Including both groups could result in more complete and nuanced understandings of change. Furthermore, this research complicates the assumption that long-term knowledge is necessarily better. Multigenerational residents’ focus on certain species reveals extremely subtle changes, but may make them less attuned to other ecologically or socially important species. Second, this work underscores the need for inclusive environmental planning. Other work in the region has shown that newcomers tend to be more involved in environmental advocacy. However, the concerns, values, and needs of multigenerational residents may be quite different. Inclusive action must look across the residential spectrum. Third, it is likely stronger constituencies for addressing environmental change could be built by carefully attending to the differences in what people care about and the ways in which they care. Because local environmental knowledge is built on local activities, interests, and priorities, it may indeed provide a stronger foundation than scientific knowledge for building the diverse communities of action necessary to address pressing issues of environmental and climate change. Finally, the job constraints of professional resource managers may steer them away from big-picture thinking about environmental change and adaptation, a finding that further reinforces the need for broad-based adaptation planning.

 

Results from this research were shared in scholarly books and articles, as well as through an interactive poster exhibit displayed at regional libraries.

 

Note: This research was conducted alongside sister projects in France, Cameroon, and Zimbabwe to provide a comparative perspective on environmental knowledge and change.
